Jim James part of all-star Bob Dylan project

The New Basement Tapes is a collaborative project featuring Jim James, Elvis Costello, Marcus Mumford and others setting recently discovered Bob Dylan lyrics to music.

Jim James part of all-star Bob Dylan project

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 10:23 a.m. EST November 12, 2014

The New Basement Tapes are, from left, Elvis Costello, Jim James, producer T Bone Burnett, drummer Jay Bellerose, Rhiannon Giddens, Marcus Mumford and Taylor Goldsmith. (Photo: Handout )

CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Bob Dylan spent most of 1967 writing at a pace that far outstripped his already prolific output. After years of rarely slowing down, he spent 1967 at his home in Woodstock, N.Y., recovering from a motorcycle accident while rethinking his career and obsessively churning out dozens of songs.

Most of them were recorded during very informal sessions with members of The Band and eventually released as "The Basement Tapes," an album now considered to be ground zero for the Americana movement. But a few dozen more were written in lyric form and tossed aside for nearly 50 years.

Earlier this year, producer T Bone Burnett asked a handful of musicians to turn those lyrics into songs and record them on the fly, in the same spirit as the original album. Two weeks, more than 50 songs, tape rolling. "Lost on the River: The New Basement Tapes" came out this week.

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, Tom Heiser and even Louisville Mayor Greg Fischer try their best to whittle the Bob Dylan collection down to their favorite songs.

Louisville's Jim James was a bit stunned to be among the invited, joining Elvis Costello, Marcus Mumford, Taylor Goldsmith of Dawes and Rhiannon Giddens of the Carolina Chocolate Drops. The Los Angeles sessions were intense but exhilarating, he said.

COURIER-JOURNAL

The New Basement Tapes, with Jim James, resurrect 1967 Bob Dylan on 'Lost on the River'

"It was a ton of songs, and kind of hilarious how fast and furious it was," said James, of My Morning Jacket. " 'You got a song? OK.' Bang, bang, bang. 'You got a song? Great.' Bang, bang, bang.

"It was more involved than just that, but that's how quick it went. We weren't trying to be like the original 'Basement Tapes,' musically, because that would be pointless, but we were trying to keep that same kind of carefree vibe where things were just kind of tossed off."

Post by courierjournal.

Each musician was sent 16 to 18 sets of lyrics in advance, and were free to write as many songs as they wished. James came up with eight, Goldsmith 18. Costello, James joked, "wrote like 850 versions of every song." When they convened in L.A., they shared what they had written.

James said it was fascinating to hear how people interpreted the same sets of lyrics.

BARS & CLUBS: 5 spots for live music

CONCERTS: Top shows to check out this weekend

"It kind of challenged the whole notion of what is a song," he said. "One person would think a set of lyrics was real fast and bashing and another would think the same lyrics were real sad and slow and beautiful. It was pretty funny."

James made a few new friends in the process, but said he's no closer to comprehending Dylan. After years of touring with him, and even joining him onstage, Dylan remains elusive.

"The only thing I've learned from all of my Dylan adventures is that you never question the ways of a wild Dylan in his natural habitat," James said, laughing. "You just don't do it. You don't question it or even think about it. He's a mystery."
